Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Harnessing Microbial Potential to Address Challenges in Groundwater Remediation
Award.AbstractNarration:
With the rise of the human population as well as industrial and agricultural activities, global sustainability is becoming an increasingly critical issue. Although environmental pollutants are of global concern, these contaminants generally differ in terms of type and concentration across the globe. Therefore, it is essential to investigate multinational pollutants and their associated degradation pathways across different geographic distributions. In this study, we will collaborate with Professor Yufang Song in the Institute of Applied Ecology at the Chinese Academy of Sciences to examine the biodegradation of China-specific subsurface contaminants and compare the results to those obtained in the United States.

A recent survey by China's Ministry of Water Resources estimated that 80% of groundwater in China has already been contaminated with chlorinated solvents, with chlorinated methanes among the most common. Chlorinated methanes such as carbon tetrachloride and chloroform have been classified as probable human carcinogens resulting from their adverse effects on organ function. Biodegradation has proven effective in multiple scenarios by transforming many toxic chlorinated compounds into environmentally benign end-products. However, the fundamental microbial pathways for mitigating chlorinated methane contamination still remain largely unknown. To this end, we will establish microcosms with samples collected from several contaminated sites to enrich and identify the microorganisms responsible for the biodegradation and biotransformation of chlorinated methanes. Identifying these microorganisms can lead to their use as predictive biomarkers in evaluating the bioremediation potential at contaminated sites. The overarching goal of this proposal is to apply established molecular tools to identify novel microorganisms, assess the bioremediation potential and develop remediation technologies in China. These shared results can be applied on a global scale and will effectively complement NSF?s current focus on the intersection of food, energy and water.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Ministry of Science and Technology of China.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background and synopsis

Countless chemicals make their way into our environment on a daily basis. Though some of these chemicals are easily broken down by nature, others can persist in our environment for decades, increasing in concentration over time. Some of these chemicals, such as the chlorinated solvents, are toxic and are classified as human carcinogens. Fortunately, nature has evolved ways to mitigate this issue using millions of microorganisms that can break down key chemicals to use in their own survival. Having already established molecular biology tools and sampling techniques, we proposed to sample key sites in China to apply otherwise localized technology in a global setting. We successfully sampled 9 different sites, obtained 13 different samples, and tested over 55 different combinations of chlorinated solvents with environmental samples. Beyond the science and technology portion of this fellowship holds several examples of intellectual merit and broader impacts to benefit our society through multiple channels.

Intellectual merit

The microscopic organisms of our planet remain a largely unexplored realm, with some estimates approximating over 99% of species that still remain to be discovered. Their ubiquitous presence on our planet exposes these microorganisms to nearly every known chemical compound, both manmade and naturally occurring. Over evolutionary time, these microbes have been postulated to take advantage of these chemical compounds in nature by breaking them down and in turn repurposing them for their own survival. Mankind has successfully taken advantage of this process by discovering and isolating microorganisms that can break down key environmental pollutants.

Many technologies have been developed specifically for otherwise localized challenges. We therefore proposed exploring the application of these technologies developed overseas to address global challenges abroad. Though the contamination profile of the US may be different compared to that of China, the basic principles of bioremediation remain analogous, which allows us to apply localized technologies broadly. In this way, we advance our knowledge and understanding of the microbial world, specifically in how these microorganisms can aid mankind in ensuring our sustainable future. Together with a world renowned toxicologist at the Chinese Academy of Sciences in collaboration with a Governor’s Chair professor at the University of Tennessee and Oak Ridge National Laboratory, our team is well qualified to address this project.

Broader impacts

The purpose of science is to benefit society, and this fellowship project is of course no exception. During this fellowship, I was able to work alongside one master’s student and two Ph.D. students at the Institute of Applied Ecology of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Together, we employed the latest sampling and molecular biology tools to isolate new microorganisms and characterize them in the laboratory. Beyond the scope of this fellowship, we fully anticipate these students to apply these techniques at new sampling sites and to impart this knowledge by training future students.

During this fellowship, I also had the opportunity to share our research at the University of Tennessee and Oak Ridge National Laboratory through three presentations at the Institute of Applied Ecology (Chinese Academy of Sciences), Shenyang Agricultural University, and China University of Geosciences. Though many of the questions following the presentation were geared towards the research, there were several questions that related more to how research is performed in the US, expectation of graduate students, and how to choose a mentor. This experience helped me see how research is conducted in a foreign country, but also provided a similar glimpse to students in China as well.

Taken together, this experience has helped myself and others understand the importance of international collaborations to address global challenges. Mankind has defined lines that we know as international borders; however, we only constitute a mere single species in the perhaps trillion or so that exist on our planet. Perhaps by taking this into account, we can cross these lines that are invisible to the rest of life on Earth and protect all life on our planet as a whole.
